text:
The most interesting thing about Claude Code is the extensibility — small things can easily compound into bigger things you didn't plan.

I started telling Claude Code to write project notes at the end of each work session: What got done, decisions made, open questions, etc.

This is a practice I've had for a long time, just a way to make it easy to pick up where I left off. 

It writes the notes itself into a file so I don't even have to write it anymore which is already really nice. (I eventually turned this into a /wrap command I run at the end of every session.)

After a few days I realized: I have project-level notes across everything I'm working on. Those could roll up into a single daily note pretty easily. So I told Claude to summarize the project workbenches into a daily log. Took about two minutes to set up.

Then I started doing my weekly review for the week. I already had seven daily summaries sitting there. 

Instead of manually going over my calendar and task list like usual, I made a command that pulls from those and drafts the first version of my weekly review — what got done, what's stuck, what to prioritize next week. 

Then I realized: I also have a file with my goals and priorities, and now I have a summary of how I actually spent my week. Why am I manually eyeballing whether those line up? 

I told Claude to audit them — compare what I said I'd focus on against what I actually did, and flag the gaps.

The gaps then inform what I need to work on next week. If I decide to reprioritize, I can tell Claude to update my quarterly goals and weekly boals based on the new priorities.

Because it has access to my Google Calendar, it can pretty easily check whether I actually have time for what I'm planning.

You can imagine how you could build more on top of this:

E.g. Send the team weekly update — make a command that takes the weekly review and reformats it for a team audience. Different tone, more context for people who aren't in my head all day. The raw material is already there.

None of these steps were planned in advance. Each was a small, obvious extension of the last primitive. 

- Daily note = summary of project workbenches. 
- Weekly review = summary of daily notes. 
- Goals audit = cross-reference of two files that already existed.

Each piece took a few minutes to set up because the building blocks were already there. 

That's the thing that's both impressive hard to convey about these CLI tools — while some single steps are impressive (e.g. the ability to one shot complex software), the more interesting and exciting thing to me is the ways they compound over time.

@TaylorPearsonMe Combine that with your daily logs of your wispr flow, your meeting transcripts and, if you really want your email sent folder, and now you have a comprehensive overview of what you did. That’s what I did :)

@runsonai Love that. Sent email is a nice one to add. I was doing meeting transcripts and google calendar and that was pretty complete. In practice, basically all my Wispr Flow goes into Claude code. So I think that may be redundant, but interesting to play with. Pretty cool times!

@TaylorPearsonMe you just described a multi-agent system. each step (daily notes, weekly review, goal audit) should be its own specialized agent. way easier to extend and debug when they're separate.

this exact pattern is what businesses need but won't build themselves.

Help me understand what converting these from a slash command into an agent would accomplish in practice?

I'm present and interacting with these processes. So having them run in the background doesn't seem like that much of an advantage, so slash commands seem to be adequate, but open to changing my mind.

Stealing this immediately, thank you. I've been building something similar with my OpenClaw, I,Claudius: Daily memory files, project scratchpads, error logs, but I hadn't wired up the rollup chain you're describing. That's the missing piece.

What's interesting to me is extending this beyond just session notes. I'm layering in premortems before any content or marketing build, tracking what actually worked vs what we assumed would work, and logging the patterns we're seeing across multiple projects. The compounding isn't just in the summaries; it's in the pattern recognition. When you can cross-reference three months of daily notes against your quarterly goals and see exactly where you drifted, that's a different kind of awareness than any weekly review gives you manually.

The "summaries all the way down" framing is right, but I'd add: it's also lessons all the way down. Each layer should be getting smarter, not just shorter.

Lol, love the name. I'm thinking about how to incorporate the lessons. 

I think my current notion is that there's a layer that sits on top of the workbenches that's something like consolidated learning where you go back through the workbenches or have Claude go back to the workbench just periodically and construct it into learnings that are then applied to making the system better. 

I'm not sure that's the right approach, but generally agree that there is something more you want out of it than just simply a record of everything that happened. And that it seems like Claude is pretty good at both creating this document and then learning from it. Though figuring out how it's such in the architecture is important and I don't think I've quite solved that.

i love that openclaw has made capturing knowledge so easy. 

a word of caution: the more you use this, the more context your llm has to sift through. you're going to want something that automatically structures these notes for you in a knowledge graph.

the ingestion is easy. keeping extraction accurate and cheap will be the hard part.
